ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed insight into the nature of civil conflict and its economic effects.
Reading all those papers *really* helped me to generate research ideas and think critically about identification in empirical work! I learned so much about what development economists do.
The syllabus was created with intention and care, and I learned a lot about the mechanics of designing papers and thinking through the theoretical frameworks of economic research papers.

I learned an immense amount about the various determinants and effects of intrastate conflict in the developing world. I learned how critically analyze empirical papers and draw out their conclusions while also realizing their limitations. I also learned how incredibly frustrating and tedious it can be to write your own research paper.

I learnt a lot about the various aspects of civil conflict, and also about econometric methods and how to read papers in the economic literature. I learnt how to carry out an empirical project and to work with STATA.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is essentially reading papers and talking about them, which I don't like as a teaching model.

Strength: a great selection of papers, appropriate for a senior undergraduate audience. Professor Ibanez knew the field extremely well. Weakness: the reading responses took a lot of time and weren't even graded - I think it would have been worthwhile to include them in the class participation grade.
I honestly think the course was pretty much perfect the way it was.
This course was great. I think the best part was the class discussions, so I would have loved to spend more time on that.

Not sure how this will be relevant since Professor Ibanez is a visiting professor and this course will never be offered again, but: papers are all very interesting and the professor knows a ton in the field; a very good exposure to conflict literature and to econometrics in general. Empirical project and the empirical work could have been a bit more guided/structured, especially since most students don't have that strong a background in econometrics coming in (alternatively the department really needs to work on their core classes).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd only recommend this course if you're passionate about the subject matter. I wasn't, and didn't enjoy it much at all.

If this course is structured similarly to when I took it, then you should take it! Conflict is a subset of the development literature, and you spend the course reading and discussing a ton of papers. You also write your own empirical paper, which is hard but definitely a rewarding exercise.
This was my favorite econ class so far at Yale.
Definitely! If you are interested in the different determinants and effects of intrastate conflict I would highly recommend taking this class.

Again, not sure how this will be relevant since Professor Ibanez is a visiting professor and this course will never be offered in future, but - yes; the papers you read are really interesting and you learn a lot throughout the semester. It's well-structured and you actually get to learn from reading each paper, and it's a good introduction to the literature. Also this class is pretty econometrics-heavy, so you get to actually apply what you've learnt in 131/132.

Definitely! Professor Ibanez is absolutely great! You'll learn so much on how to read economic papers - you'll also really really learn how to conduct economic research and empirical analysis which is great prep for writing a thesis
